title: Momir of Lučica
text:
Momir of Lučica (; 1804–13) was a <a href="Serbian%20Revolution">Serbian Revolution</a>ary commander who participated in the <a href="First%20Serbian%20Uprising">First Serbian Uprising</a> (1804–13).
He was born in <a href="Lu%C4%8Dica%2C%20Po%C5%BEarevac">Lučica</a>, at that time part of the <a href="Po%C5%BEarevac">Požarevac</a> "<a href="Nahiye%20%28Ottoman%29">nahiya</a>" in the <a href="Sanjak%20of%20Smederevo">Sanjak of Smederevo</a> ("Belgrade Pashaluk").
He was a "knez" before the uprising. He joined the uprising at the beginning, in 1804, and rallied people in the Morava and <a href="Stig%20%28Serbia%29">Stig</a> regions. He participated in the <a href="Siege%20of%20Po%C5%BEarevac">Siege of Požarevac</a> (1804), besieging the town from Morava to Salakovac. His <a href="trench">trench</a> was situated in Gornja Mala. Momir and <a href="Milenko%20Stojkovi%C4%87">Milenko Stojković</a> cleansed the southern part of the Požarevac district from Ottomans. After the liberation of Požarevac, <a href="Kara%C4%91or%C4%91e">Karađorđe</a> appointed him the "knez" of Morava ("Moravska knežina").
<a href="Paulj%20Mateji%C4%87">Paulj Matejić</a> begged for the hand of Momir's daughter for his son Budimir, and they married.
Momir had a mansion in Lučica, fenced by <a href="palisade">palisade</a>.
His son <a href="Ivo%20Momirovi%C4%87">Ivo Momirović</a> (fl. 1812–13) was a "vojvoda".
Momir is regarded the third, after <a href="Milenko%20Stojkovi%C4%87">Milenko Stojković</a> and <a href="Petar%20Dobrnjac">Petar Dobrnjac</a>, most important revolutionary in the <a href="First%20Serbian%20Uprising">First Serbian Uprising</a> from the Požarevac area, based on courage, reputation and participation.
